In Milwaukee, some charter schools are doing better than the public schools, but they also have more advantages and freedom--and some aren't doing as well. They may be required to take students with IEPs but how many provide special education services, and staff who are well trained at working with students with disabilities, or even noticing the signs of an LD?
For parents caught between the state's heavy handed control, including their educational requirements for all students regardless of ability (a situation made worse by the adoption of Common Core State Standards), charter schools look attractive. But why don't we simply fix the public schools and cease the top-down, clunky approach to education? Let's stop punishing top performing public schools with rules that may not fit them and get honest about the flaws of charter schools.

If a charter is not "accepting" all kids they should not receive public funds; state or federal. By "accept" I mean not only have open enrollment but also not have policies and practices that will weed out slow learners.

Given a choice as to who's helping our kids more, I'm going to choose the educators who are pointing out that the emperor has no clothes over the charter advocates trying to convince us all that he's got a lovely outfit.

As a former inner city school teacher, I think I understand that part of the obstacle to better sharing is a somewhat natural resentment by the public school teachers. Being a teacher in a poor urban school is the toughest job in town, in my opinion, and it's so tough that after a while you start to doubt that anyone can appreciate exactly how tough it is. So when the charters do well, with what you may feel are "unfair" advantages such as more selective kids, and then when you're told that, "See, this isn't so tough, now just do what they do," your reaction is not going to tend to be, "Hey, gee whiz, I finally found out what I was doing wrong!" Instead, your reaction is going to be to get mad, distance yourself from the charters, try to debunk their accomplishments, and certainly not try to emulate them. I'm reporting from Milwaukee, which I think is the nation's capital of charter and choice, and this is a huge problem here--the energy of both sides is simply consumed attacking the other.

This is understandable, except IT"S NOT HELPING OUR KIDS (excuse my shouting). It's time for a cease fire and to now bring everyone together, hold our experiments up to the light, identify the practices that help the charter and choice kids do better, and then figure out how we can now work together to institutionalize them and take them to scale.

I have sat in on common room discussions of students discussing the world's political systems, debating whether Princeton's study about the US' government is accurate, commenting on the disparities faced by immigrants in our own city and the treatment that homeless people often receive.

Intellectual discussion is still alive and well, though it does not always occur in the classroom.

While it may be easy to dismiss student bantering at Wesleyan as demonstrative of the entire university system, there are still pockets wherein creativity and problem-solving rather than solution-killing exist, and oftentimes, those discussions happen at one am, over cups of black coffee in between essays, rather than in a crowded classroom.

"It is impossible for the State of New York or even the Country as a whole to prosper without a thriving middle class."

I wish that were so but it is not, at least not here. New York City is thriving, even though its middle class is not. The prosperous don't need a middle class. All they need are servants who can commute in from some tolerable distance to provide for their needs.

Common goods will always tend towards 'socialism' because essential goods that effect life, death, and the survival of society as a whole cannot be entrusted the 'whims and wiles' of capitalism; where the phrase 'tend towards socialism' implies a highly regulated market.

Open land, natural systems, air, water, and energy have always fallen into this category, as have some elements of communications, transportation, food, and shelter.

Now, in the information age, communications, and transportation are emerging as areas that potentially need a 'lot more tending'.

It is, however, about freedom of speech and philosophy.  I find it interesting that so many are applauding the progress of accepting alternative lifestyles as perfectly normal.  But, there is a problem with "progress" when you insist on censoring opposing views.  With these hot button issues, many are afraid to say how they feel about them.  The blowback can be dangerous and frightening.  Kinda like the anti-choice folks attacking clinics and doctors because they don't approve.  There should still be room for expression of opinion as long as it's not threatening or hateful.  For the record, I'm tired of having every celebrity's sexuality on display.  I really don't want to know, and if you insist, I will just turn to something more important and interesting.  Maybe the progress is not caring one way or another.  It's your business; keep it to yourself.

Ah, EJZimmerman, it is so hard not to be able to say every hateful thing you want to say. But this isn't a case of censorship. No one is stopping you from saying whatever you want. It is just that now people will use their freedom of speech and call you out. Ah, the good old days when everyone agreed with you. Were you then concerned with how you were "censoring" others? Or how  cowed a lot of gay people felt when saying something positive about gay people was dangerous?

To those commenters who want to minimize the media's coverage of Sam's openness about his sexuality: can you not see that history has been made here?  And why?  Because American sports (and America at large) has been hideously, cruelly homophobic until quite recently.  And your minimization is only a softer form of the same prejudice.  Sure, you can quibble about the premise of the article and discuss the finer points of the game -- but in doing so, it sure feels like you'd just rather not hear about an important aspect of this story: that a competitive aspirant declared that he is gay, and was not passed over.  As for concerns that future gay aspirants will become litigious, well, if you cannot see that this event will actually make that less likely -- and if you cannot see that your implication that gays (as a minority group) are somehow automatically likely to ask for some kind of special treatment, then perhaps you should look in the mirror and ask what kind of message you are sending about inclusion and fairness with your comments.  And, oh, by the way, this is not about sex.

To E.T. Bass - in my neighborhood, the only option for reasonably fast Internet is Comcast. Sure, there is DSL and probably even dial-up or satellite service, but Comcast has a monopoly on high speed service. It shouldn't matter whether I use that service to do HD video conferencing with my office, upload/download software that I created or purchased, or to watch videos on Neflix. I am paying for the bandwidth.
If Comcast doesn't like it, they should charge different rates for data consumption or something like that - not charge the information providers such as Netflix. That's the same as getting paid twice.

Please don't think of NetFlix raising their price from $7.99 to $8.99 as just One Dollar.

Think of it as a 12% increase. Which is what it is.

Not really small potatoes, huh?
I beleive antitrust is already in shreds. No one will beleive that DSL is even close to fiber or cable in performance.

Could you post the URL? Thanks.

Notwithstanding Mr. Carr's foolish trumpeting of the defeat of SOPA, which, at least in its essence, was a necessary reform to protect copyrighted works on the Internet, his attack on FCC Chairman Wheeler's proposal to permit broadband ISPs to use price to discriminate against content and/or providers of content is well taken.

I and others have pointed out that the D.C. Circuit struck down the FCC's 2010 Open Internet Order (Order) on the grounds that it inconsistently regulated broadband ISPs differently than other information service providers, suggesting that if the FCC reclassified broadband ISPs as telecommunication services, its Order might have withstood judicial scrutiny. And Mr. Carr and other reporting in the NYT have described the other evils and defects in Chairman Wheeler's proposed "net neutrality."

However, Chairman Wheeler's proposal would also violate well established principles of antitrust law in that it would permit Comcast and other ISPs, which provide original and/or sub-licensed content, to raise the price of competing content, e.g., Netflix, so as to increase their competitive advantage against that competing content, not by competing but by using their monopoly on broadband Internet service to raise the price of competing content. That is a patent violation of antitrust law, or it would be but for the fact that the FCC is doing it. But for the FCC, Chairman Wheeler's proposal violates Sherman 1 and 2, Clayton, and the Robinson-Patman Act.

I very rarely agree with anything Sarah Palin has to say, but I fully agree with her comment that "that hopey-changey thing" is a sham.  The President's appointment of Mr. Wheeler, a cable and cellular lobbyist, as FCC Chair is a prime example of the President's craven corporate capture.  So who's surprised? No one can be elected president who isn't already or in the process of becoming corrupt - the necessary campaign money is too big, too bloody and too dirty.
Rockyboy: what do you suggest, a chairman with NO industry experience? A community organizer, perhaps?

Obama's FCC, like much of the rest of Obama Administration, is a sham and shills for Wall Street and favored corporations.

Obama campaigned on net neutrality.

But now Obama's FCC seeks to end net neutrality.

The Internet is a public utility, and Internet providers need to be regulated as public utilities.
The instant any provider decides my Internet speed by wheather they get paid by anyone other than my self, is they day they can pick up their (pieces of) equipment from my driveway.

If Comcast was required to rent its infrastructure, point (a) in my original post, then AT&T, Verizon, Time Warner, Google, etc would provide the competition.

Competition and transparency are always the key. Comcast can keep prices high and quality low because installing infrastructure is so expensive. Requiring Comcast to rent capacity, for a reasonable profit, will at least drive down costs. Perhaps if upgraded infrastructure is installed, the installer could have exclusive rights for several years.

I am a user of the Internet and I pay a service provider to use the Internet - to receive content. I also pay a provider to receive telephone service. In the latter case the caller to me is treated equally. Why should it be any different for the Internet content provider. The provider pays to use the Internet as one does the phone, but all users - senders and receivers should be equal. To allow a sender of content more power than others is wrong; it is not allowed on phones. Internet and phones are common carriers; let us keep net neutrality as we have phone neutrality.

Dan
E.T.B. ... rentDVD's? Where? Blockbuster is bust.

It's certainly true that there are countries that provide better internet service to their citizens than does the U.S., but I believe it's quite an exaggeration to say that we are "lagging behind practically every other country in terms of speed and far more costly than anywhere" (else).  Unless things have improved tremendously over the past four years, Germany, for one, is far behind us, for example.  I wouldn't be surprised if there aren't quite a few European, South American, African, and perhaps even Asian countries who also have internet services that are far behind what we have here.  None of which is to say, of course, that we shouldn't be doing far, far better than we are, but, as in far too many areas of contemporary American life, corporations have way too much power in controlling how our society operates in order to benefit their bottom line and negatively impact "we, the people."   It's definitely interesting to see what happens when too different industries decide that their respective interests are actually in opposition.

And competition is almost certainly a dream. Cities and towns everywhere have sold easement rights to various providers and there is more than a good chance that those deals all preclude there being any other competing fibre in those easements.

There’s a Times article-- Brothers Battle Climate Change on Two Fronts, May 10—about another set of brothers, the Nordhauses, these working to try to solve our global warming problems, instead of causing them. One is a Yale economist, the other a DC energy lawyer who writes climate change regulation.

We need a writeup directly contrasting the lives and work of the Nordhouses vs the Koch brothers—the biggest financiers of continued pollution and media propaganda to justify it.

In fact let's them do a climate change super bowl debate on TV prime time using the 2 sets of brothers. That should attract media buzz and spotlight the opposite poles.

The Nordhouses can tell about their long family background in New Mexico, and show how they put their intellectual talents to work for our environmental and public health.

The Kochs can tell how their father made a fortune working in Stalin's Soviet Union, the profits forming the basis of their inheritance. Then how they have used America's laws to increase those inherited billions, then put that money to work to influence state govts, and finance propaganda of the anti climate change science deniers.

Nothing like contrast of personalities to help the public understand the issues.

I went from thinking of spiders as terrifying, repugnant intruders in my home to beautiful, delicate, useful, welcome guests who are apparently more like us than I would have imagined. I hope articles like this will help stop the indescriminate killing of these very complex creatures.

spiders (these species at least) may become more individuated in style and role when living in stable groups. humans, however, may actually do both--become more conformist, i.e., like others, and more individuated. this is possible because, unlike most other species, our psyches are divided into multiple states, levels, degrees of awareness. commonly called "the unconscious" this "adaptive multiplicity" renders us, as we know, pretty complicated and enigmatic creatures.
Fascinating!  I've always protected the webs of garden spiders, but I think I'll still have to get medieval on the brown recluses and black widows that want to hang around my back door...
watching my dogs trying to catch their own food the other day I was beginning to doubt evolution, but this article quickly brought me back into the fold, thanks for some very interesting writing!
